title: Senegal Extends Sale of $719 Million Local-Currency Bond
summary: Senegal has pushed back the closing date for a 400 billion CFA francs ($719 million) sovereign bond by several days, the lead arranger for the offering Invictus Capital & Finance SA said in a Linkedin post.
content:
Senegal has pushed back the closing date for a 400 billion CFA francs ($719 million) sovereign bond by several days, the lead arranger for the offering Invictus Capital & Finance SA said in a Linkedin post.

Scheduled to be the nation’s final public offering of 2025, the sale on West Africa’s UMOA-Titres market is now planned to close four days later on Dec. 26. The government is seeking to raise the notes in three, five, seven and 10-year tranches at 6.4%, 6.6%, 6.75% and 6.95% respectively, Invictus said.

title: Saks Mulls Bankruptcy After Raising Billions for Turnaround
summary: Saks Global Enterprises, facing limited options ahead of a more than $100 million debt payment due at the end of this month, is considering Chapter 11 bankruptcy as a last resort, according to people with knowledge of the situation.
content:
Saks Global Enterprises, facing limited options ahead of a more than $100 million debt payment due at the end of this month, is considering Chapter 11 bankruptcy as a last resort, according to people with knowledge of the situation.

The company is also weighing additional ways to shore up liquidity, including raising emergency financing or selling assets, the people said, asking not to be identified because they’re not authorized to speak publicly. Separately, some Saks lenders have held confidential talks in recent days to assess the company’s cash needs, according to other people familiar with the matter. Those discussions have focused on a potential debtor-in-possession loan, a form of bankruptcy funding.

title: Gold and Silver Rise to Records on Rate-Cut Bets, Global Risks

content:
Gold and silver rallied to fresh all-time highs on escalating geopolitical tensions and prospects for more US rate cuts.

Spot silver rose as much as 2.4% to trade above $70 an ounce for the first time. Gold was near $4,500 an ounce, extending gains after its biggest one-day jump in more than a month. Traders are betting the Federal Reserve will follow three straight interest-rate cuts by lowering the cost of borrowing again next year, which would be a tailwind for non-yielding precious metals.

title: Lamont: Suspending Wind Leases Bad for Costs
summary:
Gov. Ned Lamont (D) told Balance of Power wind power is essential to bringing down energy costs in New England. 

The US is suspending leases for all five wind farms under construction off the East Coast, the latest blow to an industry that’s been targeted repeatedly by the Trump administration as part of its attack on clean energy.
The US Interior Department announced the move Monday, citing national security concerns as the massive turbines may interfere with radar systems. The suspension will let the administration work with developers and states to mitigate any security risks, the department said in a statement.
The projects impacted are Vineyard Wind 1 off Massachusetts; Coastal Virginia, which lies off the coast of its titular state; Revolution Wind, near Rhode Island; and Empire Wind 1 and Sunrise Wind, both off the coast of New York. The five projects represent about $28b in total committed capital, according to BloombergNEF. (Source: Bloomberg)

title: Bank of Canada Uncertain If Next Rate Move Will Be Cut or Hike
summary: Bank of Canada officials agreed on holding the overnight rate at 2.25% earlier this month, but are unsure whether their next policy shift will be to lower rates again or to raise them.
content:
Bank of Canada officials agreed on holding the overnight rate at 2.25% earlier this month, but are unsure whether their next policy shift will be to lower rates again or to raise them.

In a summary of deliberations of their Dec. 10 decision, policymakers said the “high level of uncertainty” made it “difficult to predict when and in which direction the next change in the policy rate would be.”

title: Sable Gets Federal Nod for Controversial California Pipeline
summary: A federal regulator approved the restart of Sable Offshore Corp.’s contested California oil pipeline that leaked 3,000 barrels of crude along the Santa Barbara coastline a decade ago.
content:
A federal regulator approved the restart of Sable Offshore Corp.’s contested California oil pipeline that leaked 3,000 barrels of crude along the Santa Barbara coastline a decade ago.

Sable’s shares rose about 30% Tuesday after it said its plan was signed off on by the Department of Transportation’s Pipeline and Hazardous Materials and Safety Administration. The move follows last week’s determination by the regulator that portions of the key oil conduit, the Las Flores Pipeline System, is under the domain of the federal government and not California. State environmental groups are poised to push back.

content:
China’s local borrowing for infrastructure spending is on pace to hit a six-year low, as Beijing clamps down on risks in a strategy shift that calls into question its promise to stop an unprecedented investment slump.

Less than 3.02 trillion yuan ($429 billion) in this year’s new provincial government special bond quota is available for infrastructure projects after more than 1.38 trillion yuan of such notes has been sold to repay the authorities’ off-balance-sheet debt, according to Bloomberg calculations based on official data. title: Tricolor CEO Collected $30 Million in Year Before Alleged Fraud
summary: Tricolor Holdings founder Daniel Chu collected nearly $30 million in compensation in the year leading up to the subprime auto lender’s collapse amid alleged fraud, according to a lawsuit filed by the trustee overseeing the company’s liquidation.
content:
Tricolor Holdings founder Daniel Chu collected nearly $30 million in compensation in the year leading up to the subprime auto lender’s collapse amid alleged fraud, according to a lawsuit filed by the trustee overseeing the company’s liquidation.

Chu “defrauded Tricolor by using corporate funds to pay for lavish personal expenses and by forcing the company into paying him tens of millions of dollars in bonuses (on top of his executive salary),” trustee Anne Burns said in court filings last week. That compensation was “premised on his ability to deliver exceptional financial results — results that were the product of the fraud.”

title: Won Jumps After Korea Vows ‘Strong Determination’ Over Currency
summary: South Korea’s won strengthened after the authorities said excessive weakness in the currency isn’t desirable and foreign-exchange markets will soon see the government’s “strong determination.”
content:
South Korea’s won strengthened after the authorities said excessive weakness in the currency isn’t desirable and foreign-exchange markets will soon see the government’s “strong determination.”

The currency rallied after the central bank and finance ministry said in a joint text message that they had held a number of meetings over the last two weeks to discuss the won’s recent weakness. The ministry also announced a package of new tax measures Bloomberg Terminal to help stabilize the foreign-exchange market, while the country’s National Pension Service said it had started new FX hedging.

title: General Atlantic, Kraft Group Bet $490 Million on Mexican Soccer Ahead of World Cup
summary: A syndicate including General Atlantic and a subsidiary of New England Patriots owner Kraft Group is making a $490 million investment in Mexican soccer ahead of the 2026 World Cup.
content:
A syndicate including General Atlantic and a subsidiary of New England Patriots owner Kraft Group is making a $490 million investment in Mexican soccer ahead of the 2026 World Cup.

The group agreed to buy a 49% stake in Ollamani Group, which owns Club America, one of Mexico’s biggest soccer teams, as well as the 88,000-seat Azteca Stadium in Mexico City, where the sport’s premier tournament will kick off, the companies announced in a joint statement. The new entity will be known as Grupo Aguilas.

title: Baby Bonds vs. Trump Accounts
summary: A new savings vehicle, dubbed “Trump accounts,” is designed to help the rising generation of American children build wealth into adulthood. Under the multitrillion-dollar tax and spending bill signed by President Donald Trump in July, the federal government will contribute $1,000 to accounts set up for every American baby born in the next few years. Darrick Hamilton, Henry Cohen Professor of Economics and Urban Policy at the New School, is behind a comparable concept known as "baby bonds," which he sees as a means to granting more social mobility and agency to young people regardless of family income levels. Professor Hamilton compares and contrasts his idea with the Trump administration's mechanism with Alexis Christoforous and Isabelle Lee on Bloomberg Businessweek Daily. (Source: Bloomberg)
content:
00:00

What is, I guess, the main difference between baby bonds and the Trump accounts? Because on their face, there seem to be a lot of similarities. Well, conceptually, the goal is to provide access to asset building by way of having some financial capital so that you can get into that building. The problem with the Trump accounts versus baby bonds is baby bonds focus on what actually is the problem. It's one of endowment, essentially the way wealth is created, as wealth begets more wealth. It's having a large enough nest egg so that you can get into a home or get into an education without debt, or to be able to have some capital to start a business. The Trump accounts essentially emphasize savings by way of the tax code. So in an ironic way, it's structured in a way that's potentially going to subsidize those that have the wherewithal to raise capital in the first place. What does it signal to you when billionaires step in to fund used wealth building programs? Are we seeing it as innovation that government couldn't achieve on its own, or is it just a quiet shift away from maybe public responsibility? I mean, I applaud philanthropy that desires to be vanguards and trying to create pathways to democratize wealth. However, however, the mechanism in this case is only feeding into a bad system. The federal government should not be ultimately subsidized for their duty. We shouldn't be reliant on the charitable contributions of a billionaire for our salvation. But what a billionaire can do is provide demonstration, be a catalyst, seed some some momentum so that we ultimately can have them invest. And, you know, I'll make one other quick point, which is when you think about the $6.4 billion, which is a huge number, it requires context. So two context points. One is it's contextual to that $4 trillion big, beautiful bill that was referenced at the beginning of the segment. So if we're thinking about the ways in which the federal government is spending wealth towards advancing access to asset building for the population, that 6.4 billion deserves context to that $4 trillion, which is from our public regress. And then the other context, about 80% of children between the ages of zero and ten will have some access to this donation, this regress. But if you were to disaggregate that, that amounts to about $250 per child. Right. So essentially, that's not going to be the catalyst. So it's distracting a little bit. You know, some countries have done this pretty successfully, right? I know. I believe Germany is among them. They'll give an allowance, a monthly allowance to parents for for kids of a certain age. Some countries use it as an incentive to get people to have more children. It's now these baby bonds have been implemented in, let's say, Connecticut since 2023. I believe they were the first state. How are things going? Oh, it's still the infancy there, but how are things going? I mean, Connecticut is a really great model and it's a state, so it doesn't have the capacities of the federal government. But here you have a scenario with every Medicaid birth will receive 30 $200 automatically at birth. And the Treasurer is managing that money in a collective fund in an astute way with responsible investing, where the projections are that the children, you know, low income children born as part of a medicaid birth from rural to urban areas throughout the state will have about 12 to 18000 as some seed capital to begin wealth building. Any you know, other examples would be the U.K. did it. They didn't fund it to the extent that we would call for in the U.S. And then here's perhaps even the best counterfactual. The United States has done similar programs with the GI Bill. That's about right. We have a history of doing this. Do you think that programs like these have an influence to affect economic policy long term, or do you think to create risking a system that just really hinges on, to your point, philanthropy of maybe rich individuals or big corporations? And that's exactly why it should be a government responsibility. And here's the point. This is not charity. This is an investment. So if you believe in the market, if you don't believe in the market regardless, again, it's pretty simple. The way wealth is created, it is that down payment to put you in an asset that passively appreciates over your life. So if you are authentically somebody who believes in transaction in the market, then you should support people having some seed capital to get into that asset. So again, it's a question of endowment, not savings behavior. Is there anything about the Trump accounts that you actually like? I mean, we have to I think we can agree that, you know, the concept I mean, the heart's in the right place. You Well, I mean that to sit at the attention of. On trying to make sure that we democratize access to wealth. That's a good thing. But to structure the 529 structure, we have lessons from that where, you know, 529 saving tax provision savings so that we can provide access to college for our children. The bottom half percent of earners essentially don't participate. Only about 2.5% of Americans participate. So there are really good ways we can do it. My fear is that we co-opt a good idea. It's a really good idea. We have pathways to really facilitate a good value for our American economy, which is inclusion. We just got to work on the delivery. To Alexis point, there's the idea of corp match welfare embedded here. Are there any upsides to that? What should policymakers be cautious about? I apologize for laughing, but the phrasing of of of corporate welfare again, I it I take the Dell's is being not disingenuous but really trying to be supportive. I think there's better ways there's more catalytic ways they could spend that $6.4 billion. But at the end of the day, the American people don't want to be at the whim of billionaires. And then there are other aspects as well that we should be leery about, which is state private partnerships for which we have to be concerned about the potential for grift when we're relying on billionaires to provide economic security for the American people. So if if we're thinking, you know, look, a lot of folks are not going to take advantage of a 529 plan, is that because they don't have the money to do it? Is that because they don't know they exist? Is that because a lot of Americans cannot be left to their own devices to save for themselves? I mean, think about how, you know, some of our our programs like Social Security came to be. It's because it was supposed to be some sort of a safety net. So. So is it a good idea for the government to put aside some money for folks who might not otherwise do it? I mean, that actually is a great idea. But just how in the mechanisms by which we do it, that's the problem. So it is the case that clearly we have an affordability crisis in this country so people don't have the wherewithal to save en masse. And that's a big reason why people don't participate in a 529 counts, not as if they don't love and adore their children and desire for them to have savings. It's wherewithal. And then the other big point is for those that have amassed wealth in America, it's not active saving lives, driving debt. And by active savings income that we actively save, it's passive savings. It's that down payment. It is critical for young adults to really have some capital so that they can get into that automatic vehicle to save.

title: PBOC Signals Steady Support With Focus on Long-Term Growth
summary: China’s central bank reaffirmed its supportive monetary policy stance while signaling continued caution toward aggressive stimulus, reinforcing a shift toward securing long-term stability over immediate fixes.
content:
China’s central bank reaffirmed its supportive monetary policy stance while signaling continued caution toward aggressive stimulus, reinforcing a shift toward securing long-term stability over immediate fixes.

The People’s Bank of China reiterated it will guide borrowing costs to continue hovering at a low level, according to a Wednesday statement following its fourth-quarter monetary policy committee meeting. The bank repeated a pledge to step up “cross-cyclical” policies, a phrase suggesting it aims to look beyond short-term volatility and avoid excessive stimulus that could create structural imbalances.

title: Ruble’s World-Beating Rally Poses New Risk for Russian Economy
summary: Russia’s ruble has outpaced every major currency against the dollar this year, a rally that caught policymakers off guard and threatens to undermine the nation’s wartime economy.
content:
Russia’s ruble has outpaced every major currency against the dollar this year, a rally that caught policymakers off guard and threatens to undermine the nation’s wartime economy.

The ruble has strengthened 45% since the start of the year and is trading near 78 per dollar, within touching distance of levels seen before Russia’s full-scale invasion of Ukraine nearly four years ago. Over the past 12 months, the appreciation has been the strongest since at least 1994, the data show.

title: Intel Declines; Dynavax Rallies; Nike Ticks Higher
summary:
- Shares of Intel (INTC) fell in the early session after Reuters reported that Nvidia halted a test that uses the chip manufacturer’s 18A technology to produce its chips.

title: US Weighs Conference to Rebuild Gaza in Fresh Ceasefire
summary:
The US and its allies are renewing their push to hold a conference on Gaza reconstruction, people familiar with the matter said, as the Trump administration looks to inject fresh momentum into a ceasefire between Israel and Hamas after a string of setbacks.
Washington has been discussed as a potential venue for the conference that could happen as early as next month, according to the people, who asked not to be identified discussing private conversations. Egypt is among several other locations also being considered, one of the people said.
That person said the event would probably take place only after officials fill out the Board of Peace that will oversee a transitional government and whose creation was spelled out in the ceasefire that ended the fighting between Israel and Hamas and was signed in October. Bloomberg's Dan Williams reports from Jerusalem. (Source: Bloomberg)

title: Consumer Debt is Possible Headwind for Retail, Says EY-Parthenon's Auchincloss
summary:
US consumer sentiment rose in December by less than expected, remaining depressed amid lingering affordability concerns.
The University of Michigan’s final December sentiment index climbed 1.9 points to 52.9, according to a report released Friday. The median estimate in a Bloomberg survey of economists called for a reading of 53.5.
“Despite some signs of improvement to close out the year, sentiment remains nearly 30% below December 2024, as pocketbook issues continue to dominate consumer views of the economy,” Joanne Hsu, director of the survey, said in a statement.
The current conditions gauge slid to a record-low of 50.4, while a gauge of expectations climbed to a four-month high. Consumers’ perception of current buying conditions for big-ticket items deteriorated to the lowest on record. Will Auchincloss, Americas Retail Sector Leader at EY-Parthenon, breaks down the state of the consumer. (Source: Bloomberg)
content:
00:00

Consumers are showing in our monthly surveys that they're getting less and less confident in the economy as the year wears on. And there's several factors that are driving that. One is the job outlook. The biggest reason now, however, is inflation and the continued pressure on essential categories like food, housing, even debt now is sort of emerging as a topic for consumers. And so they are trying to muscle through this environment as best as they can. And that is weighing on the retail sector. And it's it's weighing a little bit on the holiday season as well. But we're seeing some pretty good numbers out of some of the retailers. I mean, I'm seeing, you know, probably three or 4% retail sales growth here in the holiday season with the e-commerce even higher than that. It seems like consumers are still spending, though. They are, Paul, and they are trying to spend on the holiday and kind of keep that basket together as best they can. But there's some underlying factors that make the headline data a little bit more, more nuanced. So the majority of what we're seeing is that that those year over year gains are driven primarily by price actions and not volume. And in fact, in our headline outlook for the for the holiday season, we sort of forecasted about a 2 to 3% year over year growth rate. I think it's coming in a little bit higher, which is good news. But the majority of that is driven by price. Almost two thirds of that is driven by price and not volume. So, you know, as a retail sector, you like to see more volume going out the door historically. And so again, it's a little bit softer. I think part of that is certain chains have really resonated with consumers this this holiday season. They've gotten the value equation better aligned to expectations. And there is some channel switching happening that appears in our survey as well. We're seeing that increase as as consumers want to sort of shop what they've always shop for, but get a better price for it in whatever channel is best suited for them. Yeah, we were talking about somebody earlier talking about shopping earlier in the show and how consumers have become much more intentional about what it is they're spending their money on. But let's talk about restaurants and bars and how we're spending on that. I mean, how did you talk about that in the survey and what did you guys find out? We do. But it has been a tough year for for the restaurant sector in general, and we don't expect that to change much going into 2026. Will What's typically an anecdote to consumer spending concerns? Yeah, I think it's a couple of things. One is that they have to have more confidence. And, you know, with all the change in the policies coming out of out of the federal government with concerns about inflation really showing up in their, you know, the receipts and some concerns about the economic outlook and a little bit of a I it's it's a it's sort of a psychological aspect of this that's really weighed on the sector. However, there are some real economic drivers because a lot of the GDP growth we're seeing is driven by what we call the three A's. So that's affluent consumers. That's asset price realization in the stock market and. It's so I'm forgetting the third day it's AI driven investment which is dealing the the the sort of the stock price appreciation. So that's propping up a lot of this. And affluent consumers in particular are really need to kind of continue that that that spending pattern as we go into 2026 if we're going to continue at the levels we're content seen today and with in terms of how we're paying for these things and, you know, consumers taking on debt, especially during the holiday season, I know that they're using a lot more buy now, pay later platforms, and that could be troubling down the road. Yeah, that that is a concern for us to monitor. And and savings in general has declined since Liberation Day. Again, as consumers try and buy what they've always purchased, but in the face of higher prices. So we've gone from a savings economy to a debtor economy, and that shows up in the macro data. That is a potential risk in the outlook for for 2026, because the question is how long can they keep doing that? And those debt levels have sort of increased generally across all income segments as well. So it's not just centered in one income segment. That's not we're not reaching sort of crisis levels by any stretch, but it is another potential headwind as we cross into next year.

So it's meeting the consignor where they are, whether they want to drop off in the store on their way to work, whether they want a van pick up at 3 p.m. this afternoon on demand, they'll can book that from their app. And we're seeing the consignor the seller can more items when they interact with the store and more high value items because they're meeting with a gemologist and watchmaker. So yes, it's a place that people get introduced to our being, our brand, where a quarter of our new consignors come from, the stores, from our retail locations. But we more see a halo impact. title: Year in a word: Stablecoins
summary: In spite of efforts to bring it into the mainstream, the cryptocurrency remains one step removed from money
content:
Roula Khalaf, Editor of the FT, selects her favourite stories in this weekly newsletter.

(plural noun) Digital assets whose value is pegged to another asset

Conversations about stablecoins usually begin with what they’re not.

Digital money? Almost. Pegging a crypto token’s value to a real-world currency (almost always the dollar) makes it look like money. But even with one-for-one reserve backing — as mandated by the Trump administration’s Genius Act, passed in July — its relationship to money remains one step removed. Not everyone wants to be confronted by foundational concepts like singleness and supply elasticity while buying groceries.

Payment rails? Almost. There is a logic to putting dollars on the blockchain, particularly in the US, where merchant fees are artificially high. Small payment systems work just fine nearly everywhere else, however, so stablecoins for daily use looks like a solution seeking a problem.

Remittance systems? Almost. Some may value moving money across borders, 24/7, without the friction of security checks. But while a clearing house may cost more, it provides someone to blame if something goes wrong.

Exchange traded funds? Almost. But ETF issuers rely on independent auditors and custodians. Stablecoin issuers such as Tether, the world’s biggest, prefer a more DIY approach.

The point here is that many money-like products already exist. They are tightly regulated and issued under conventions hardened by crises. Stablecoins were born of a desire to bring new customers to the crypto casino. Secondary uses like funding illicit trade stem directly from regulatory ambiguity.

Stablecoins may benefit the US, which has a lot of dollar-denominated debt to sell. The challenge for others countries is to justify why private money should exist alongside their own currencies, while resisting the temptation to regulate stablecoins like something they are not.

bryce.elder@ft.com

title: Turkey Cenbank Will Expand Key Bond Portfolio for ‘Flexibility’
summary: Turkey’s central bank will boost government bond purchases next year to strengthen a key portfolio that’s used in managing lira liquidity.
content:
Turkey’s central bank will boost government bond purchases next year to strengthen a key portfolio that’s used in managing lira liquidity.

The central bank aims to increase the size of its government bond holdings to 450 billion liras ($10.5 billion) in 2026, up from 262.3 billion liras currently. It will also have the option to make additional purchases for the so-called Open Market Operations (OMO) portfolio, the bank said in its Monetary Policy For 2026 report. The move aims to support “operational flexibility,” according to the central bank.

title: Fed Minutes Show Most Officials Expect Additional Rate Cuts
summary:
A record of the Federal Reserve’s December meeting showed most officials see additional interest rate cuts as appropriate if inflation declines over time as expected.
Yet, some officials made clear they believe rates should remain on hold “for some time” after the December gathering.
Minutes of the Dec. 9-10 Federal Open Market Committee meeting continued to point to divisions among US central bankers and to the difficulty of their most recent decision.
“A few of those who supported lowering the policy rate at this meeting indicated that the decision was finely balanced or that they could have supported keeping the target range unchanged,” the minutes said.
Officials earlier this month voted 9-3 to lower their benchmark interest rate by a quarter percentage point for the third straight time, to a range of 3.5% to 3.75%. (Source: Bloomberg)

Payroll growth remained sluggish in November and the jobless rate rose to a four-year high of 4.6%. title: Bernie Sanders Swears in Zohran Mamdani as NYC Mayor
summary: Sen. Bernie Sanders delivered the oath of office to Zohran Mamdani, swearing him in as New York City’s 112th mayor on the steps of City Hall. (Source: Bloomberg)
content:
00:00

And now it is my honor to swear in your new mayor. Ow, Ow, Ow, ow, Ow! Please repeat after me. All eyes are on Kwami Mamdani. Eyes of Francois Mamdani. Do solemnly swear. Do solemnly swear. That I will support the Constitution of the United States. That I will support the Constitution of the United States. The Constitution of the State of New York. The Constitution of the State of New York. And the Charter of the City of New York. And the Charter of the City of New York. And that I will faithfully discharge the duties. And that I will faithfully discharge the duties of the office of the Mayor of the City of New York. Of the Office of the Mayor of the City of New York. According to the best of my ability. According to the best of my ability. So help me God. So help me God. My fellow New Yorkers. Today begins a new era. I stand before you moved by the privilege of taking this sacred oath, humbled by the faith that you have placed in me and honored to serve as either your 111th or 112th mayor of New York City. But I do not stand alone. I stand alongside you, the tens of thousands of you gathered here in Lower Manhattan. Warmed against the January chill by the resurgent Flame of Hope, I stand alongside countless more New Yorkers watching from cramped kitchens in Flushing and barbershops in East New York. From cell phones propped against the dashboards of parked taxicabs at LaGuardia from hospitals in Mott Haven and libraries in El Barrio that have too long known only neglect. I stand alongside construction workers in steel toed boots and hollow cart vendors whose knees ache from working all day. I stand alongside neighbors who carry a plate of food to the elderly couple down the hall. Those in a rush who still lift strangers strollers up subway stairs, and every person who makes the choice day after day, even when it feels impossible to call our city home. I stand alongside over 1 million New Yorkers who voted for this day nearly two months ago. And I stand just as resolutely alongside those who did not. I know there are some who view this administration with distrust or disdain or who see politics as permanently broken. And while only action can change minds, I promise you this if you are a New Yorker, I am your mayor.

title: Here’s (Almost) Everything Wall Street Expects in 2026
summary: Over 700 key calls on how AI spending and government policies are set to fuel growth, inflation may prove hard to beat, private assets will continue their rise and the dollar will extend its decline.
content:
Connecting decision makers to a dynamic network of information, people and ideas, Bloomberg quickly and accurately delivers business and financial information, news and insight around the world

Connecting decision makers to a dynamic network of information, people and ideas, Bloomberg quickly and accurately delivers business and financial information, news and insight around the world

Here’s (Almost) Everything Wall Street Expects in 2026 Illustration: Jeremy Scott Diamond. Photo: Yevgen Romanenko By Sam Potter January 1, 2026

Astronomical expenditure. Uncertain rates of return. Uneven pace of adoption.

By now every firm on Wall Street is well aware of the risks surrounding the artificial intelligence boom. But when it comes to the year ahead, few advocate walking away from what they describe as a “revolutionary” technology. Across the investment outlooks from more than 60 institutions compiled here by Bloomberg News, the optimism is almost universal.

Fidelity International calls AI “the defining theme for equity markets” in 2026. The BlackRock Investment Institute says the tech will likely “keep trumping tariffs and traditional macro drivers.” NatWest spies “a powerful engine of economic expansion.” Even the most bearish firm — BCA Research, which warns of a potential US recession — stays neutral on stocks for now on the tailwind of AI’s huge capital expenditure.

“The biggest risk, to us, is not having exposure to this transformational technology,” JPMorgan Wealth Management says.

See the all the calls for 2026 ↓

When it comes to risks to the outlook, the worries are conventional. Geopolitics. Trade barriers. A weakening US labor market (BCA’s chief concern). But with the AI boom holding up, the Federal Reserve seen loosening monetary policy, and further support arriving in the shape of President Donald Trump’s “One Big Beautiful Bill Act” and Germany’s fiscal stimulus, the general consensus is for the global expansion to rumble on.

“Regional policy shifts suggest a more supportive macro backdrop for global growth in 2026,” writes State Street. “With an inflation trajectory trending lower, US policy rates likely to fall as the Fed takes stock of a softening labor market, and policy levers turning stimulative, we have a supportive environment for risk assets.”

Still, optimism over returns has a limit. Valuations of key assets remain elevated, with many equities looking pricey and credit spreads extremely tight. US tariffs remain in place, acting as a brake on global growth. Inflation is still not vanquished.

“There is a disconnect between the positive short-term environment for risk assets, and a broader structural instability,” says Fidelity. “Global fragmentation, a depreciating dollar, US Federal Reserve independence, and AI capex trends are themes to watch in 2026 and beyond.”

Bloomberg’s annual compilation of outlooks for the year ahead features more than 700 calls, presented here for easy analysis and comparison. They talk of an environment where the AI spend and government policies are adding fuel to growth at an unusual stage of the business cycle. They argue inflation won’t quite be tamed as a result, and that central banks may not have the room to maneuver that markets currently expect. Private assets will continue their ascent. The dollar will continue its decline.

The calls have been divided into sections covering the key themes and assets. Each section has a short summary, and the calls will load in approximate order based on the level of conviction displayed (highest-conviction calls appearing first). The filtering tool will allow you to view the calls from multiple specific institutions at once.

This is what the finance world’s best and brightest see in the year ahead.

title: Gao: US Venezuela Move Ends 'Pax Americana'
summary: Victor Gao, VP at the Center for China and Globalization, tells Bloomberg that Beijing condemns the US action against Nicolas Maduro, calling it the end of an era. (Source: Bloomberg)
content:
00:00

Venezuela's acting President says she is inviting the U.S. to work with her country after an American operation to capture President Nicolas Maduro. The US swooped into Caracas over the weekend, seizing Maduro and flying him to New York to face drugs and weapons charges. President Trump said the US plans to run Venezuela with elections due eventually. We're going to run everything. We going to run it, fix it. We'll have elections at the right time. The main thing you have to face is a broken country. Well, joining us now is Victor Gao, Vice President at the Center for China and Globalization. Victor was ex Chinese leader Deng Xiaoping's English interpreter in the 1980s. Victor, good to have you with us. What's your sense? How does Beijing view the strike that the US made on Venezuela? I think China condemns such an act of aggression and intrusion into a sovereign country and hijacking or abducting a head of state and the first lady. This is purely, in China's view, a violation of the international norms, relations and a violation of the United Nations charter. And if the United States can do this to Venezuela, United States, or any other country, it can do similar things to any other country. And what really drives President Trump and the US government is to seize the oil assets in Venezuela. Now, this is not American assets. This is Venezuela's assets. And for President Trump to pretend that he will run the affairs of Venezuela is very presumptuous in the least and also very much destabilising the international relations. If any country can do this to the oil assets of Venezuela, they can do similar things to Saudi Arabia or to Qatar or to UAE. There will be no peace and stability in the world. So I think China wants to stand on the right side of history. And the United States, apparently, in China's view, is on the wrong side of history. This will not make America great again. This will really be a very dark moment in the U.S. history and in my best judgment, history will look back upon this event as the beginning of the end of Pax Americana, because the United States, through this act of aggression against Venezuela and against the sovereign President of Venezuela, is really starting a new phase in its development. It may eventually lead to the end of Pax Americana. No one in the world wants to be dominated by a neighboring country. Victor. Might China be concerned about its own interests in Venezuela? Because by some calculations, China has lent Venezuela about 100 billion. Of course, China, Venezuela relations are very close and we cooperate with each other fully. And this is all normal contracts. And for the United States to launch such a blatant act of aggression against Venezuela is a matter of great concern to China. And China wants to call for stability. And China wants to continue working relations with Venezuela, especially with the current government. And if there will be a new government eventually in due course, of course, China wants to maintain normal relations with the future government in Venezuela. But all this is no small matter because what the United States is doing is not only negatively impacting all the legitimate business interests of China and Venezuela, it really undermines the international norms. And if this becomes a precedent, I think the United States will strike fear in many other countries in the world. And allow me to mention philosophically, striking fear is not equivalent to gaining respect. Fear is not getting respect. And the United States will be better served if it gains respect rather than striking fear in other countries.

title: Ecofi's Georges Sees More Momentum for Europe Stocks
summary: Karen Georges, a portfolio manager at Ecofi Investments, discusses the key factors driving momentum in European equities in 2026. Georges spoke with Matt Miller and Paul Sweeney on December 31, 2025. (Source: Bloomberg)
content:
00:00

The labor market always matters. I mean, it's been a very good labor market for the U.S. for the past at least four or five years. I mean, post-COVID. So people are getting nervous about the labor market, maybe too much. We saw that the latest figures showed that you don't know, you no longer have the destruction of job creation in the private sector, which is a very good thing, because a few months ago we did have the destruction in the private, the labour market and the public market made like the whole most of the job creation during the first the first semester of of the year. So that is a positive sign. We had ECOFIN do not expect the labour market to deteriorate very much in 2026. On the contrary, we think is going to get a little bit better, especially in the second half of the year and that should help the US economy going forward. Karen, You know, we all look here in the US too much probably on the US markets where we have the S & P up 17%, the NASDAQ up 21%. But boy, the returns, the equity returns in European markets are really spectacular, superior to those in most markets relative to the US. Can you give us just a backdrop on the 2025 drivers and whether they'll still be there in 26 for many European markets? Yeah, of course. Well, the main drivers of the European markets are very different from the U.S.. If you look at, for example, in terms of styles, you see value in the in the European markets much better than growth. So like in the U.S., it's the opposite. You see growth and the bodies like this. So in the European markets, it's mainly financials, defense sector, transport, so very, very cyclical markets value segment. So it's mainly value. So it's been tough for growth investors in in Europe because as you spent a few minutes ago, you have winners and losers and most European fund managers are mostly growth like they like in the U.S. So it's been a tough year for active managers in in Europe, but it's mainly financials, defense and transport. And in regards to the difference between Europe and the U.S., for us as European investors, it's even better because since we are, the euro is our main currency. So when you look at U.S. markets in euro, it's only plus 3%. So European markets are much better than the U.S. for European investor. Yeah. And if you look at European markets in dollars, it's astounding the gains that I mean, your CAC, Carol, up 25%. If I were to have invested in dollars at the beginning of the year in Germany, the DAX, I would have gotten a 40% return if I had invested in the beginning of the year, the IBEX 35 in Madrid, 17% return. Better than buying gold. Yes, right. And that's been mainly driven care and by the banks. So it's so funny to me because the years that I spent, you know, I was in living in Germany for six years until 2022, and Deutsche Bank was trading at like 0.3 times. Book How come the European banks have outperformed by so much? It's not like the EU has figured out banking union yet, right? Well, you have three main explanations. The first one is they're mainly domestic. So obviously with the trade war with Donald Trump, investors favored domestic stocks, with interest rates that remained high both in the U.S. and in Europe. Also, people want to go into value stocks. So obviously, financials are value, as you pointed out, even though price to books are now obviously higher than six years ago. So that's also a plus. And the third the third part is the fact that they're, as I said, cyclical. So if you believe in an inflection point for the European economy going forward, to answer Paul's question about 2026, it's also positive for financials because we we expect the economy to be much better than the consensus. The consensus was around 1.1 GDP growth for next year. We could see from 1.4. So it's maybe not so much for U.S. because your your GDP growth is higher, but it relatively is very good for for European markets, if that will be the scenario for next year. So we are still very positive on Europe markets for a 2026.

title: We've Been Investing In Venezuela For One Year: Craige
summary: Markets are reacting to the news the US ousted Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro largely in stride. Jim Craige, CIO and Head of Emerging Markets at Stone Harbor Investment Partners, said his firm has been investing in Venezuela for the past year. He discussed the potential implications for emerging markets on Bloomberg ETF IQ with Scarlet Fu, Katie Greifeld and Eric Balchunas. (Source: Bloomberg)
content:
00:00

You guys have an ETF Vertis. Stone Harbor Emerging Markets High Yield Bond ETF. The Tickers V and Y where you have a 2% allocation to Venezuela. How does the news of the weekend change how you move forward? The news is very significant. So we began adding to Venezuela a little over a year ago and since then it's up a little over 100% and today it's up 30%. So the implications are the defaulted debt that we own in the fund and across our strategies has increased significantly in price, and it should continue to do so. It's trading at $0.35 on the dollar, and the claim value is between one and a half and two times that. So you do a pretty simple restructuring where we expect a lot of value out of this. And, you know, we've seen South America going through a lot of changes. Are you bullish on South America in general, buying more of the debt there? Because I see you have a lot of other countries in your portfolio. What's your take on the whole continent? Most definitely. We're very bullish on Argentina, ten and a half percent yield. We're very bullish in Ecuador, nine and a half percent yield. But more broadly, the region should continue to do very well. EMA broadly should grow two and a half to 3% above the US. I mean, Latin America will be a big part of that. So we're very excited about Latin America. On the flip side of that, I mean, digesting the news from this weekend, obviously you would think this has a lot of implications for em broadly. Are there any regions, are there any countries where you would de-emphasize the debt here? I think oil exporters more generally are probably something We don't want to be overweight right now, and that's because we would expect the supply to increase because of the Venezuela exposure. We're already in an oversupply market right now anyway, so this will not help. So we're not as bullish on oil exporters more generally. You're up that 50% since the fund came out beating EMH. Why? Congrats. What percentage of that is the currency versus the debt itself? It's all the debt. So everything is dollar denominated. Empire has done quite well. But but the dollar denominated debt is also done quite well. But let's say it wasn't like how much currency are you saving then by being in dollars? So you're saving a fair amount in the currency. The currency has a fair amount more volatility and real rates are very high. So I do think there are opportunities in places like Brazil potentially, and Colombia as well. South Africa, you had said that you were buying Venezuelan bonds about a year ago, so you had this inkling that this was a good time to start loading up. And it feels like there's very much asymmetric upside here to the to that debt, especially if there is a restructuring. What is your timeline here for restructuring? I would expect it's going to be 18 months to 24 months. Somewhere in that time frame might be positively surprised. But there's the restructuring, which will be significant for the default, the debt, but also just the amount of investment that's going into Venezuela will be staggering. So high conviction, it sounds like, when it comes to Venezuela, when it comes to what we're seeing unfold here. But that being said, what risks are you monitoring as it pertains to this situation? Well, it definitely could have a a transition that is more disorderly. It's not our base case, but that's certainly a risk that bears watching. So we spent a lot of time talking to political analysts and others in the Treasury and State Department, etc., to try to get a handle on that. But we're very confident that that's not likely. But 45 seconds, I was looking at the return attribution of your fund. The best performing country is Lebanon. Today I learned this. What's going on there? That's so good. Sure. Similar to Venezuela, you have defaulted bonds that are trading in the twenties and your claim values double that. So right off the bat, you've got a lot of upside embedded in the price, but also you've got some transformations there. It is part of the economic team in Lebanon is a good friend of ours and and a former competitor. So a lot of respect for him. But also they just passed a GAP law which allows for some of the bank debt restructurings to be recognized and dealt with. So we're very bullish on law on Lebanon long term.

title: 'GRIFT' ETF In Trump Era Hits A Wall
summary: The Tuttle Capital Government Grift ETF — ticker GRFT — is designed to target firms with apparent ties to Washington powerbrokers, from cabinet officials to stock-trading lawmakers. Yet no major exchange has agreed to list it, according to Matt Tuttle, chief executive of Tuttle Capital. Bloomberg's Isabelle Lee discussed the story on "Bloomberg ETF IQ" with Scarlet Fu, Katie Greifeld and Eric Balchunas. (Source: Bloomberg)
content:
00:00

Tell us a little bit about what this ETF, the proposed ticker is graffiti aims to do. So this was filed in June. We wrote it because it was cheeky. It was new. It's like graffiti, grift. And then the ETF name is Government Grip. It's designed to target firms with political ties to Washington. So Matt Tuttle, the CEO of the issuer behind this, said they will scrape speeches, whether it's commentaries or they will look at the companies that members of the Congress disclose basically anything. And it's not specifically tied to any politician or any administration. He just says that I want this to be could translate political influence into investable insights. So that was in June and we were waiting when will it launch? And then so I was asking him and asking him in waiting. And then months after we found out that the exchange wants to list it. So a big no from the three exchanges reportedly. What is the path forward here for Matt Tuttle and for this fund? I think if it's a no, then he there's nothing you can do. So according to him, his only hope is Texas. So it remains to be seen. Texas exchange, which is set to start operating, I think earlier, early this year. But if not that, I asked him, what about Canada, What about others? Are you open to rebranding it and stuff? But he said no, he wants it to be grift for now. He wants it to be bigger. So he doesn't want to change the name of it or the ticker for it. Eric Can an ETF actually launch as an ETF without an exchange behind it? No, not really. I mean, that's the whole point of the name exchange traded fund. So it wouldn't be an ETF at that point to be like a GBTC. Now, Nance, by the way, to me seems equally cynical. This is the Democrat trading ETF and it's got 260 million. So it's interesting if Cruz is the GOP one Nance has the more assets and does better though they've drew a line with grift. I think Texas will list that the people who run the Texas exchange are from CBOE and I think they were the most liberal of the three exchanges. So I have hope there. But if not, you know, this is such a total story. I'm holding out for his alien tech ETF. And you said this is the first ETF you can think of that all the exchanges rejected. I've never heard of this. This is like, you know, like gangster rap back in the day, like Walmart wouldn't carry the album or something. It's like, I've never heard of this, but this feels very on brand with Matt Tuttle, right? Yeah, it's a little bit of a provocateur. Very much so. But it's interesting because last year Katy wrote a story that it's a record year for launches, flows and volume. But now Eric was the one who said it's also it's like the parents are saying no because the ETF industry is like a teenager pushing boundaries using Eric's words.

title: Trump Snatches Maduro But Leaves Regime in Charge for Now
summary: After President Donald Trump stunned the world by saying the US plans to “run” Venezuela, uncertainty over what that means and who is in charge loomed over the South American nation.  Ousted Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro was an indicted prisoner on a flight bound for New York by the time his Vice President Delcy Rodríguez — who Trump said would partner with Washington to “make Venezuela great again” — denounced the intervention as “barbaric” and a “kidnapping.” Adding to the confusion was that the White House offered few details about what running an oil-producing nation of about 30 million people would entail. Bloomberg News National Security Team Leader Nick Wadhams joins Bloomberg Businessweek Daily to discuss. He speaks with Carol Massar and Tim Stenovec. (Source: Bloomberg)
content:
00:00

What's the Trump view of the Monroe Doctrine or the Trump iteration of the Monroe Doctrine? What does that look like? Well, as usual, with this administration, we've had very conflicting accounts on precisely what that is. You had Rubio essentially saying other other countries, adversaries, the U.S. need to stay out of the Western hemisphere. He said they are not going to allow a situation where Venezuela's oil reserves, the largest in the world, would be controlled by adversaries such as Russia or China. And then President Trump, when asked about that, basically said, you know, sure, Western Hemisphere and all that. But this is really about an individual country. And everything we hear at this point is essentially in the president's thinking, it was based on a real direct animus he had with Nicolas Maduro. I mean, what you see now essentially is them allowing the vice president, Delsey Rodriguez, to become the acting president. And, you know, she comes essentially from the same group, the Chavistas that Maduro belonged to. So we may see a change in policy from Venezuela under U.S. pressure, but we're not really seeing a major rotation in the in the group of people who are ruling the country, aside from Maduro himself. Right. Big changes need to happen for there to be a different direction for Venezuela going forward. Having said that, Nick, I wanted to ask you, how important is Venezuela to U.S. national security? You know, it's a great question, Carol, because there are a lot of conflicting accounts on that. I mean, if you ask an international law expert, they would say there is no direct threat to the United States from Venezuela. You would essentially need Venezuela to basically be attacking the United States to put forward an argument for self-defense. But, you know, this administration has taken a much more expansive view of U.S. authority, saying that the drug running that they allege was passing through Venezuela was killing thousands and thousands of Americans. And then they also say, you know, the oil issue and the and the influence of U.S. adversaries. So they have argued that Venezuela was cultivating ties with Hezbollah and Iran and China and Russia, and they're not going to allow those adversaries to gain a toehold in the Western atmosphere. And so, therefore, there was a direct threat to the U.S. national security. And, you know, that's really the sort of the foundation on which a lot of the U.S. legal arguments rest in this case for the sort of stepped up aggression against Venezuela. So they're really leaning into that. But, you know, in terms of a direct existential threat to Americans based on what we would conventionally think of as what constitutes the use of force in self-defense, the legal experts argue that it's just not really there. What about when it comes to what's actually happening on the ground in the experience of Venezuelans and to what extent the administration actually has that in mind? I was struck that we didn't hear much of that during the press conference in the past when the U.S. has played a role in ousting leaders. It's talked about the role of democracy and humanitarian challenges and countries and use that as a way to talk about why regime change was important. And now we're getting reporting that from our Bloomberg News team. Venezuela Regroups with New President. Old repression tactics the government has detained. On Monday morning and early afternoon, at least two, at least seven journalists and members of the press. What's the relationship there? Well, no, certainly, I mean, we have not seen the administration put forward the idea of human rights or concerns over democracy as a major reasons reason for this. And, you know, that's evidenced by the fact that aside from Maduro, as I mentioned, they've basically left the rest of the regime in place. And by all accounts, at least from our reporting, it looks like the the regime is is essentially cracking down on any notion of dissent. So we don't really get a sense that that's driving things. On the other hand, the administration has also said, you know, Maduro was an illegitimate president and they cite the election whereby it's widely believed that he got the return to the presidency via illegitimate means. But then that's contradicted on the other side by the fact that President Donald Trump has essentially said, you know, Marina, Maria Conchita Machado's is they don't believe that she can she's strong enough to essentially be the president, even though it was her group, her proxy, who international observers believed essentially won that election. So it's a lot of conflicting talk from the administration and the president and his administration really putting the emphasis on the oil and this drug running idea and the idea that this was strictly a law enforcement operation against Nicolas Maduro himself. The other thing, Nick, that we've been thinking about, you know, why Venezuela, but also and Erik Schatzker brought this up, like why is this happening now? When I think about the last couple of weeks and how much time we spend talking about. The Middle East again. And Israel and Gaza. Certainly Ukraine and Russia. I'm just curious, you know, why this is happening now. You know, again, a question that we have been trying to answer for a long time. We do know that the Trump administration had sought to pressure Nicolas Maduro to leave power in the in the first term. So there was a maximum pressure campaign and a push to recognize then opposition leader Juan Guaido in administration at the official time were saying, you know, Maduro is on his way out. It could be weeks, certainly no more than months. We then had a lull during the Biden administration and this sort of came back to the fore under the second Trump administration, where you have elements of the administration like Marco Rubio, who draws a direct line between Venezuela and Cuba, where he wants to see that regime ushered from power. But then a lot of the reporting we saw, we've also seen in the last several days suggest that there had been a long conversation between the U.S. and elements within Venezuela to push for a negotiated exit for Maduro, based in part and sort of pushed in part by some of these views within the administration. And Trump, for one reason or another, basically ran out of patience. And it felt that an even stronger degree of animus toward Maduro himself and so just decided to go ahead with it. And it was really nothing. No, not any sort of broader or strategic resonance beyond that.

summary: A top JPMorgan's banker, EMEA co-head Mathieu Wiltz, said the US bank is 'bullish' in its capacity to deliver more IPOs this year. (Source: Bloomberg)
content:
00:00

What is the mood, Max, here when it comes to dealmaking prospects in 2026? Thank you, Tom. And thanks online as well for having me this morning. So clearly, the letter, the sentiment is positive and we see the pipeline that we have both in money and in in IPO is very robust. We had a very strong year last year outside of the, let's say, three months post tariff announcement. But since the month of August, we see, you know, the peak of activity and we think that 2026 should be a good year for IPO. Again, there is strong demand from the from the markets. When we listen to clients as well, there is a real willingness to to come to the market and benefit from from from that window. As you said as well. We are in the middle of doing a European tool. So with some of my partner and we are traveling across Europe this week and Middle East next week trying to be with clients on the early part of the show as well and make sure that we stay close to them, We listen to them and we try to help them to navigate into that difficult geopolitical landscape. Markets are doing well, but clearly the geopolitical points are clearly more difficult to anticipate and navigate. But we are bullish. To your question, clearly on our capacity to deliver more IPO this year. Well, Matthew, you bring in the geopolitics. So let's go to that and of course, the unprecedented events in Venezuela. Has that has that changed, changed the view that the teams view, the House view? How are you thinking about that in terms in terms of the impact, the economic impacts, the risk impact, maybe the impacts on deal making as well? Has it adjusted your outlook for 2026 this so. So this one is difficult to assess right now. That just happened. We see that when we look at the market and the performance of the market yesterday, equities did pretty well. We look at the issuance as well because we expect a strong January as well for issuance. Just yesterday in the US, we issued more than 61 billion of bonds, but the markets as a whole and credit spread are doing extremely well. Even if those volumes are impressive, when we look at the at the Brent yesterday, it was relatively stable. We have a target at $58 for the end of 2026. So decrease from where we are at the moment. But clearly that was Venezuela. We have to reassess. We are looking at that. We have our reserve team. We don't expect based on the on the market reaction, I mean, any significant drop now when we analyze the situation, everything will depend of how strong the US will be into the the day to day politics in Venezuela. Because if you look at it, Venezuela is one of the biggest sale. So if you take Venezuela plus the US plus part of Guyana as well, that means that if the US are really driving that, they're going to potentially influence 30% of the of the crude production. So that definitely will have an impact. But it's very early stage and difficult to assess for the moment, but that's something that we monitor every every minute now. Okay. Good morning to you. As you said, the geopolitical situation very much in flux under review as you describe it. Clearly, the fiscal impulse here in Europe, thinking about your your emir geography, the fiscal impulse is certainly an area of focus. And I noticed that you are opening a new digital bank in Germany this year. I wonder what your hopes and dreams are for that fiscal push in Europe and what can it what it can deliver for it for for banks and for J.P. Morgan? So I think that and I'm a European citizen and I've been a gypsy for 25 years, but I've been always in Europe and I'm a strong believer in Europe and the fact that we can do more. When we listen to the Draghi report and we are definitely 100% aligned to what has been affirmed and proposed. We think that with more cooperation, more elements, stronger leader in Europe, Europe can do better. And we live in a world where now economically we have to fight against the US, Asia, part of the Middle East as well. So I think Europe getting together is definitely a must. So and you could think that it's counterintuitive for a US bank to say that because you could think that we would benefit from from more, let's say, fragmentation in Europe. But this is completely wrong. And Jamie Dimon has been very vocal about it as well, having a strong Europe, having more cooperation, having stronger leaders. But that means that in Europe, every country need to accept that they may win in one industry. If we have more M & A and maybe France will have more finance or automaker or healthcare, maybe Germany will do something in Italy or the Netherlands. But we need to make sure that, like authorities and company are allowed to for M & A and cross-border activity. And if we have stronger player in Europe, that's going to be the only way that we are going to be influential, let's say globally against the big player in the other regions. And that's one of the areas where many have been trying to craft some cross-border M & A has been within the banking sector. We heard from a European commissioner recently, Matthew, who was saying that actually it is US banks that managed to navigate the fragmented banking landscape across Europe better than perhaps the the European ones do, because they are partly because they are outsiders. I mean, does that chime with your experience? Do you find as Americans in Europe, it's relatively easy to navigate that fragmented banking landscape? I would not say that. I think that when we talk to clients and I think most of the feedback that we receive from clients is like several of the American banks and Jp morgan being the first one, we've been consistent and we deliver like very strong support and services even during volatile periods. During the global financial crisis, during COVID, we were always there and we never scaled back from our positions. And we have that role across all countries in Europe. The issue that we see in Europe for some of the European players is like it's very hard for them to be strong in every country. Many of them are very strong in their country, but it's very hard to be to have a presence and to be a leader in every countries. And that's why we think that we need more women and we need for Europe to have stronger player and cross country player. So you could see that in a way that would go against our position and maybe against our market share. But we think that having a stronger leader at the end will increase the wallet and will be better for the business overall for Europe. And as JPMorgan in that current environment, we think that we will be alongside some of the strong European banks having having, let's say, most of the market share and do it do a good business in that environment. So that's why we are we are so pushing for more consolidation and more cross-border, I mean, in Europe as a whole. Yep. Matthew, good morning. It's Guy. Couple of questions on the credit market. How much how much of what you guys are going to do this year is going to be datacenter origination in credit is how different does the market in Europe look compared with the United States or Asia? What is the story here in Europe when it comes to that part of that segment of the market? So, I mean, clearly the it's been a big theme last year both in Europe and in the US. But that doesn't the financing we've done a lot. There is truly needs as well also for for CapEx expenditure. That's one place that we like. We want to continue to do business. I know that there is some noise about the fact that we could have a bit of a, let's say, boom at some point in the in the area. That's why we need to be cautious as well. And I think that's the nature of our business, is to be with clients alongside them and give them liquidity when they need to do investments, capital expenditure, but also make sure that we choose the right partner. And I think that based on our experience, because we've been in the credit market for more than 200 years, from private to public, we have that experience. And I think that's the benefit as well. For clients who work with partners like Jp morgan is that we can deliver on the whole range of products. If you want to do private and more private transaction, we've like a very different set of investors. We can deliver on that. If you want to do more public transaction broadly syndicated, we can deliver on that and we have the experience and that's why we are trying to demonstrate because that market is changing with new newcomers as well. So we have to fight to protect capital. Are getting the I'm getting the sense here that maybe you think that some people aren't being careful enough in this space. Clearly, these are not Jp morgan clouds. Of course not. But do you think there are others that maybe aren't being maybe quite as quiet as doing that diligence as well as they should? Maybe. I think it's maybe I mean, for sure. And we see that every day in the market. We are not trying to hide as well. And I think when we published our results a quarter ago, I think Jamie has been very open as well and transparent about the situation we had with tricolor in the US. So I'm not trying to hide and I think issues can happen to everyone. I think that was also a good reminder that for all of us internally that we need to stay highly focused. We need to double check on everything. I think we live in a market today where there is an excess of liquidity to to the market overall. So that's why we need sometimes to refuse to do a transaction if we think that especially covenants are not there and do not give us enough comfort. There is also a big is that more and more co-investing are coming with us or with some of the private equity player. So we were already doing it for us. But having co-investors that put even more pressure on us to make sure that we do the right due diligence and to and that we do invest and lend only where we are 100% comfortable.

content:
The US initial public offering market is bracing for a rush of deals that could rival or even top the pandemic-era record, with a lineup including some of the most closely watched private companies in technology, finance and crypto – and potentially the biggest listing of all time.

Companies raised $47.6 billion via IPOs on US exchanges last year, excluding blank check companies and financial vehicles, data compiled by Bloomberg show. That’s an increase from the year before but still well shy of the $195.2 billion raised in 2021. Conditions are as favorable as they’ll ever be, with the S&P 500 Index expected to build on its 16% gain in 2025, and the CBOE Volatility Index, Wall Street’s so-called fear gauge, hovering near a five-year low.

title: Venezuela’s Dwindling Oil Storage Imperils Output: Kpler

content:
Venezuelan oil production is at risk of severe decline within weeks as storage tanks approach full capacity and many ships steer clear of Caribbean waters to avoid a US naval blockade, according to maritime intelligence firm Kpler Ltd.

Daily oil output in the South American nation could slump to 600,000 barrels by next month if the blockade persists, Kpler said Tuesday. That would compare with an average of 1 million barrels as recently as November.

content:
Newly-inaugurated New York City Mayor Zohran Mamdani ’s housing agenda is facing its first test as the city balks at the bankruptcy sale of thousands of rent-stabilized apartments owned by Pinnacle Group, where residents have railed against living conditions.

City authorities on Monday asked a bankruptcy judge to delay a Chapter 11 auction scheduled for Thursday, saying they need more time to both evaluate a proposed $451 million deal to Summit Properties USA and “explore any potential alternatives.” After the buildings were put into bankruptcy last year, Summit offered to buy dozens of buildings in Brooklyn, Manhattan, Bronx and Queens in the form of a stalking horse bid, meaning the transaction is subject to potentially better offers at auction.

title: Ziemba: ‘Drill, Baby, Drill’ Everywhere Except the US
summary: Global markets remained resilient as investors grow accustomed to President Trump's unorthodox military operations, viewing them as temporary shocks rather than long-term risks. Instead of panicking over the Venezuela incursion, traders are focusing on AI growth, potential rate cuts, and a stabilized oil supply. Rachel Ziemba, founder of Ziemba Insights spoke to Bloomberg’s Horizons Middle East and Africa anchor Joumanna Bercetche on the new world order created by President Trump. (Source: Bloomberg)
content:
00:00

Rachel, good to have you with us. And I know we can discuss so many different things from the geopolitical ramifications, the market ramifications of what has gone down at the start of this year. Let me start with the geopolitical question and whether you think this so-called new world order that people are talking about or the dawn role doctrine that President Trump has introduced in Latin America, do you believe that this is going to intimidate or will it actually embolden some of the other authoritarian regimes around the world? Jumana, pleasure to be with you. Happy New Year. It's been quite a busy start to the year for all of us. I think it may embolden other sizeable continental powers like China and Russia in their own spheres of influence, even as they're facing more pressure in the Western hemisphere that the U.S. has indicated is part of its sphere of influence. You know, we continue to have questions of what, you know, how seriously President Trump is taking the end to the conflict in Ukraine and, you know, where China is concerned. They don't want a new trade war, but they're there. You know, maybe there are lots of questions about lessons for Taiwan. Yeah. And I think what was interesting in all of this is at no point at any point in the last couple of days that Trump even mentioned the word democracy. This was not a takeover that was fought on ideological grounds. It was pragmatic. And I think they've been pretty clear and transparent about the need to get access to Venezuela's oil. The announcement overnight that Venezuela is going to send over 50 million barrels to the US. How again, do you think this changes the world's calculus and the relative power nexus in the world that you follow very closely, which is energy and energy supply? Yeah. I mean, in a way, there are two things. One, I'm reminded of the fact that just over a year ago, you and I met and Dubai on this program and we talked about drill, baby, drill. And the place in the world that we're drilling is not up is actually the United States. The domestic supplies are, you know, sort of are stalling. But elsewhere in the hemisphere, this is really increasing in a way. I see this sort of transfer of barrels as both a down payment from Venezuela, but also it's a, you know, and maybe an extorted down payment, but it's also a way to avoid a shut in of production as the US maintains this blockade. Venezuela was running out of storage space because they weren't able to sell the oil to China. When we look at the amount here, this is a sizable amount, but it's, you know, 50 million barrels. That's equivalent to about a fifth of what the U.S. imports every month. It's about two months maybe of Venezuelan exports to China, a little bit less than that. So the big question is also how quickly this comes and whether U.S. business is going to be ready and interested to invest in Venezuela. But overall, we're really seeing a Donald Trump wanting cheaper, you know, cheaper oil and, you know, a might makes. Right. A pragmatic trend, as you say. Yeah. Yeah. Well, you have a brilliant substack, which I enjoy reading very much. And it's called Weaponize the Economy. And I think this is really the manifestation of that weaponizing the economy. And I just wonder, Rachel, whether, you know, you look at the price action in precious metals, industrial metals, the massive run up we've seen in copper and others the last couple of months, do you think that that is an expression of that of some sorts and the fact that there is a global sovereign race to get their hands on these critical minerals and on these critical metals that are so key for the transition and also for for I. Yeah. And copper is linked in to electrification across the board. If anything, even as global oil demand is flattening, demand for power is not. It is going up to the data center demand due to all of the electronics that run our lives. And copper in particular has both a demand story but also has had supply shocks beyond copper. I think what we're really seeing is a push to build out more processing, particularly for critical minerals. And then of course we've got gold and we've got silver, which are much more of a sort of inflation play, I might say, and are really the way that people are trying to play a potentially weaker dollar and to play this these questions of central bank independence and whether the US economy will be run hot going forward. So I do think there's still, you know, probably not going to see as big a run up in gold as we did. And in 2025, it's kind of hard to repeat. But a number of these metals we should continue to see some support for. Yeah. Rachel, always great to have you on and happy New Year to you. Rachel Samba, founder of CMA and Sites.

summary: Bets on artificial intelligence companies have dominated US equity markets for three years, powering a 78% gain. A growing number of investors are now wagering that run, led by the Magnificent Seven, is about to end.
content:
Bets on artificial intelligence companies have dominated US equity markets for three years, powering a 78% gain. A growing number of investors are now wagering that run, led by the Magnificent Seven, is about to end.

Mounting concerns about AI’s ability to deliver seismic changes on the American economy — and the fat profits that would come with them — has turned investor euphoria about the technology into agita. That’s driving cash into shares of the “other” 493 companies, particularly ones that would benefit most if an expected uptick in economic growth comes about.

Stellantis NV’s car production in Italy slumped by nearly a quarter last year, highlighting the struggle to revive manufacturing at its original sites with political leaders pushing for commitments to keep factories running.

A rebound in the fourth quarter prevented an even steeper decline, Italy’s FIM-CISL labor union said at a press event in Turin. As of the end of September, passenger-car output had fallen Bloomberg Terminal 36% year-to-date. Total production including vans declined 20% to 379,706 units in 2025, the union said, with cars accounting for 213,706 of those.

content:
Ousted Venezuelan leader Nicolas Maduro may have done more to hollow out China’s presence in his economy than Donald Trump ever could.

As the US president moves to root out rivals and adversaries like China days after toppling Maduro, lost in the aftermath is that his 12-year rule already led to an unwinding of financial ties with Beijing. The threadbare partnership that’s endured belies what Maduro described as his country’s “perfect union” with China — in comments made to President Xi Jinping ’s envoy just hours before the shock capture last weekend.
